subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Developing Strategy to Solve Business Problems
headline: Learn how to develop the relevant strategies to solve problems facing your business in this free online course.
description: Problems are a part of daily living. Consequently, most people look for solutions to resume their lives. Unfortunately, the same is true of businesses: difficulties will inevitably arise and the skilful development of problem-solving strategies is key to the success of any business. This course explores how to identify the problems in your business and develop and execute the appropriate problem-solving technique to manage them.
courseDescription:
Starting up, sustaining and growing a business are no mean feats. They can be intensely painstaking and sometimes discouraging due to specific problems that arise in the industry. These business problems are inevitable. Anyone who ventures into any business without anticipating hurdles will likely be severely disappointed. In many cases, these problems are commonplace in the business sphere. However, they may present themselves in forms peculiar to you alone, either because of the nature of your business, the environment or some other factor, which makes solving them even more tasking.

It may be a daunting challenge to tackle some of the problems in your business. But regardless of the seriousness of the situation, solving it is imperative or your business will be adversely affected. This course will help you develop the right strategy to tackle these problems. You will learn to identify impending issues that may not already be obvious to you, thus letting you take precautions before things get out of hand. Further in the course, you will see how setting your objectives and defining your key results can lead to your sought-after success. We explain this process using a concept known as ‘Objectives and Key Results’ (OKR).

As you progress, you will eventually come to the core of the course as we bring the importance of brainstorming to the fore. This, among other concepts, involves a set of thought patterns known as ‘expansive’ or ‘reductive thinking’, which are thought processes that help to stimulate the right kind of strategy for solving your problem. Next is planning and execution. Finally, after developing the strategy, you have to act on it. The final phase of this course will guide you to do this effectively. Applying the methods outlined in this course can save your business from closing down. So enrol in this course and start learning today.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page
slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • On the completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Identify the major factors that cause the problems that arise in your business.
    • Indicate issues and place them into a problem statement
    • Define your business objectives and key results.
    • Recognize potential strategies to solve business problems.
    • Analyze all necessary data before a brainstorming session to decide on the right strategy.
    • Evaluate the progress of your problem-solving plan by means of an action tracker.

  • Case Study

  • Imagine City Scraps a local workshop that transforms customers’ household junk into sculptures, jewellery, and other art.

    According to City Scraps’ website, customers can bring any scraps and junk to the workshop, say what they’d like their scraps to be turned into, and return one week later to pick up their new one-of-a-kind work of art.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Unfortunately, there’s a problem: Lots of people love City Scraps' creations, but lately, they have had significantly fewer customers coming into the workshop.

    How can they fix their problem? Would move to a new workshop that’s 10 times bigger help? Or would it be a better option to figure out what the problem is and how important it is to solve it?

    Rather than diving into a solution without thinking it through, City Scraps should focus on identifying the exact problem and coming up with a strategy to solve it. No matter what kind of business you run or are a part of, this is how you can solve any problems you encounter.

  • Case Study

  • Imagine you’re about to go for a sail in your sailboat, but you notice there’s a small leak. Rather than set sail and slowly sink, you decide to repair the leak to enable safe sailing. Of course, you can’t just dive into boat repair without a plan.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • So, what should you do? You should make a plan. You should figure out some important things like how many holes you would need to repair, where the holes are, and what tools would you need. You should also know what the repaired boat would generally look like. When problem-solving, it’s important to know what your problem is. But just as important is knowing what success will look like. A fancy but useful way to think about what success looks like for you or your business is by defining objectives and key results, or OKRs for short.
  • So, what are O’s, and what are KR’s?
    • Objectives are: what you want to achieve.
    • Key Results are: how you’ll know if you’ve achieved it.

  • Case Study

  • Case Study

  • Imagine Princely Prints, a small print shop owned and operated by the Prince family.
    The Prince family prints everything on standard computer paper, but the word on the street is that customers want more options than that.
  • This gets the Princes thinking about what products they could be printing. Putting their heads together, the Princes come up with a whole bunch of different products they could print, including business cards, glossy photos, stickers, oversized posters, and even hats and shirts.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • So, what’s their next step? Ideally, once the Princes have come up with ideas of what they could print, they should narrow those down to what they should print.

    The same applies when creating a strategy to solve a problem at work: Start by thinking of many possible solutions before deciding which ones work best for you.

  • So, what’s their next step? Ideally, once the Princes have come up with ideas of what they could print, they should narrow those down to what they should print.

    The same applies when creating a strategy to solve a problem at work: Start by thinking of many possible solutions before deciding which ones work best for you.

  • Case Study

  • Imagine Carol and Carmen have an online business that sells caramels. Business is taking off, which is great, but they’ve run into a problem: They don’t have enough storage space.

    Luckily they know their objective, which is to increase storage capacity, and they even know how much they need to increase it.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Carmen goes online and finds a decently sized and affordable shelving unit to put in their kitchen. After all their strategizing, though, the shelving unit arrives unassembled. Now, to turn their problem-solving strategy into a reality, the two of them are going to have to build and install the shelves themselves.

    How? A good way would be for one of them to read the instructions while the other assembles the shelves.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this course you have learned that:
    • Having a structured framework to approach problems–specifically one that uses a shared language, so everyone understands concepts–can shape the culture of your business and make your team’s efforts worthwhile.
    • To define your problem, you should start by creating a problem statement. This should be a few short but detailed sentences about your problem.
    • Prioritize problems with the most impact, focusing your problem statement in terms of the scope by identifying parameters, such as the set of customers you’ll focus on or the region you’ll be working in.
    • You should make sure your objective focuses on what you’re trying to achieve and not how you’ll do it.
  • Expansive thinking: To find the right strategy, start by coming up with a lot of ideas of what you could do.
    Reductive thinking: Once you have a lot of ideas of what you might do, narrow these down to the ones you should do.

  • Lesson Summary

  • In this course you have learned that:
    • Having a structured framework to approach problems–specifically one that uses a shared language, so everyone understands concepts–can shape the culture of your business and make your team’s efforts worthwhile.
    • To define your problem, you should start by creating a problem statement. This should be a few short but detailed sentences about your problem.
    • Prioritize problems with the most impact, focusing your problem statement in terms of the scope by identifying parameters, such as the set of customers you’ll focus on or the region you’ll be working in.
    • You should make sure your objective focuses on what you’re trying to achieve and not how you’ll do it.
  • Expansive thinking: To find the right strategy, start by coming up with a lot of ideas of what you could do.
    Reductive thinking: Once you have a lot of ideas of what you might do, narrow these down to the ones you should do.
